item.title: Bessent Says Fed ‘A Little Off,’ Flags Signal From Two-Year Rate
item.description: Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent questioned Federal Reserve policymakers’ judgment on interest rates, reiterating his view that two-year Treasury yields are a signal that their benchmark rate is too high.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Lai

media:content.media:description: US Secretary of the Treasury Scott Bessent

item.title: Bessent Says Trump to Decide on Any Extension of July 9 Tariff Deadline
item.description: Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said that President Donald Trump will make the call on any extension of talks with trading partners past the July 9 deadline for higher tariff rates to kick back in.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Lai

media:content.media:description: Scott Bessent, US treasury secretary, during a Bloomberg Television interview in New York, US, on Monday, June 30, 2025. Bessent indicated it wouldn’t make sense for the government to ramp up sales of longer-term securities given where yields are today, though he held out hope that interest rates across maturities will be falling as inflation slows.

item.title: IMF Warns Trump Tax Bill Complicates Cutting Debt in Medium Term
item.description: The International Monetary Fund warned that President Donald Trump’s tax bill nearing final passage on Thursday is likely to complicate the task of reducing the US fiscal deficit and debt burden in the coming years.
item.dc:creator: Eric Martin

media:content.media:description: The International Monetary Fund headquarters in Washington, DC.

item.title: Poland’s Glapinski Sends Competing Signals After Surprise Cut
item.description: Poland’s central bank Governor Adam Glapinski said this week’s unexpected interest-rate cut was not the beginning of a cycle of monetary easing, even as he held out for another potential reduction in September.
item.dc:creator: Agnieszka Barteczko

media:content.media:description: The financial district in Warsaw, Poland, on Wednesday, May 7, 2025. Poland’s central bank cut interest rates for the first time since October 2023 as eastern Europe’s biggest economy prepares to elect a new president in a little over a week’s time.

item.title: Mortgage Rates in the US Slide for a Fifth Week, Hitting 6.67%
item.description: Mortgage rates in the US dropped to the lowest level since early April.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Epstein

media:content.media:description: A home under construction in a residential development in Vacaville, California, US, on Thursday, June 26, 2025. Mortgage rates in the US, declined for the fourth consecutive week, with the average 30-year fixed loan falling to 6.77%, the lowest level since early May and down from 6.81% the previous week, according to Freddie Mac. Photographer: David Paul Morris/Bloomberg

item.title: Kenya Growth Misses Forecast as Tourism, Manufacturing Lag
item.description: Kenya’s economy performed slightly worse than expected in the first quarter, weighed by its tourism and manufacturing sectors.
item.dc:creator: David Herbling

media:content.media:description: Tourists in the Masai Mara National Reserve, Kenya.

item.title: Canada Exports to US Keep Falling as Tariffs Curb Shipments
item.description: Canada’s share of exports destined for the US shrank to the smallest proportion since at least 1997, excluding the Covid pandemic. Shipments to other countries reached a new high, led by gold exports.
item.dc:creator: Randy Thanthong-Knight

media:content.media:description: Tractor trailers cross the Peace Bridge at the Canada-United States border in Fort Erie, Ontario, Canada, on Tuesday, March 4, 2025. The Trump administration may announce a pathway for tariff relief on Mexican and Canadian goods covered by North America's free trade agreement as soon as Wednesday.

item.title: Fed’s Bostic Urges Patience Amid Uncertainty, Resilient Economy
item.description: Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta President Raphael Bostic called for patience amid uncertainty over economic policy and said a wait-and-see approach can help to ensure officials don’t have to reverse course on interest rates.
item.dc:creator: Jonnelle Marte

media:content.media:description: Raphael Bostic, president and chief executive officer of the Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta, speaks during an interview in Atlanta, Georgia, US, on Friday, Nov. 3, 2023. Bostic said policymakers have time to watch how the economy is evolving and be patient when it comes to interest-rate moves.

item.title: US Service Providers Expand at Modest Pace as Employment Slows
item.description: US service providers barely expanded in June, helped by a pickup in business activity and bookings even as an index of employment contracted the most in three months.
item.dc:creator: Nazmul Ahasan

media:content.media:description: A worker stocks shelves at the George J. Falter Company Inc. warehouse in Baltimore, Maryland, US, on Tuesday, April 9, 2024. The US Census Bureau is scheduled to release wholesale inventories figures on April 10. Photographer: Nathan Howard/Bloomberg

item.title: Morocco Mulls First Islamic Bond in Years, Says Monetary Chief
item.description: Morocco may sell Islamic bonds in 2025 after a seven-year hiatus, the central bank governor said, amid an investment drive for the men’s football World Cup in 2030.
item.dc:creator: Souhail Karam

media:content.media:description: Aerial view over the river Bou Regreg, medina, Hassan Tower and Mohammed VI Tower in the city Rabat at sunset, Rabat-Sale-Kenitra, Morocco. (Photo by: Arterra / Marica van der Meer/Universal Images Group via Getty Images)

item.title: US Job Growth Picks Up With Help From Public Education Hiring
item.description: US job growth exceeded expectations in June as an unusual surge in public education employment masked a slowdown in hiring across the rest of the economy.
item.dc:creator: Mark Niquette

media:content.media:description: Recruiters and job seekers during a job fair in Chicago, Illinois. Photographer: Jamie Kelter Davis/Bloomberg

item.title: Romania’s Bond Rally Gathers Pace With Rating Risk Reduced
item.description: Investors in Romanian sovereign bonds are welcoming long-awaited measures to curb the budget deficit, with the reduced risk of a credit-rating cut likely to extend a rally in the country’s debt securities.
item.dc:creator: Andras Gergely, Irina Vilcu, Peter Laca

item.title: BOE’s Bailey Warns Stablecoins Threaten Public Trust in Money
item.description: Bank of England Governor Andrew Bailey warned that the rise of stablecoins risks undermining the public’s trust in money as experts warn of the threats posed by the expanded use of dollar-backed cryptocurrencies.
item.dc:creator: Tom Rees

media:content.media:description: Andrew Bailey Photographer: Patrick Bolger/Bloomberg

item.title: Here Are the Key Takeaways From the US Jobs Report for June
item.description: Here are key takeaways from the US employment report for June, released Thursday:
item.dc:creator: Chris Anstey

media:content.media:description: A worker moves a pine wood plank at Woodstock Wood sawmill in Saugerties, New York. Photographer: Angus Mordant/Bloomberg

item.title: Middle East Conflict Was a Factor in Chile Holding Rates in June
item.description: Chile’s central bank said its decision to hold rates last month was the best option given higher uncertainty stemming from the Middle East conflict, including doubts on the war’s impact on inflation and monetary policy.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Malinowski

media:content.media:description: Pedestrians in the Plaza de Armas in Santiago, Chile, on Sunday, June 1, 2025. Chile’s economy grew more than expected in April as mining output jumped, offsetting a drop in manufacturing and retail, according to the central bank’s main gauge of monthly activity.

item.title: Vietnam Still Finalizing Trade Deal Already Announced by Trump
item.description: Vietnam said negotiators are still working to finalize the details of the trade deal announced by US President Donald Trump, providing little clarity to businesses and investors beyond the tariff rates disclosed so far.
item.dc:creator: Nguyen Dieu Tu Uyen, Nguyen Xuan Quynh

media:content.media:description: Operations at the Tan Vu Terminal at Haiphong Port in Haiphong, Vietnam.

item.title: Tracking Every Trump Tariff and Its Economic Effect
item.description: For the full experience visit: Tracking Every Trump Tariff and Its Economic Effect
item.dc:creator: Jeremy Diamond, Adrian Leung, Jane Pong, Christopher Udemans, Jason Kao

item.title: Trump’s Vietnam Deal Stokes Asia Concern as Trade Deadline Looms
item.description: Vietnam’s trade deal with the US is a wake-up call for Asian governments grappling with the reality that higher tariffs are here to stay.
item.dc:creator: Shruti Srivastava, Ruchi Bhatia, Philip Heijmans

item.title: Guggenheim’s Walsh Says Fed Has Room to Cut Interest Rates Now
item.description: The Federal Reserve has room to cut interest rates as elevated uncertainty and the impact of tariffs ripple across the economy, said Anne Walsh, chief investment officer of Guggenheim Partners Investment Management.
item.dc:creator: Jayna Rohslau

media:content.media:description: Anne Walsh Photographer: Zak Bennett/Bloomberg

item.title: ECB Officials Flagged Danger of Strong Euro at June Meeting
item.description: European Central Bank officials highlighted potential dangers for exporters from gains in the euro, according to an account of their June meeting that brought an eighth cut in interest rates.
item.dc:creator: Jana Randow, Mark Schroers

media:content.media:description: The European Central Bank headquarters beyond containers at a freight terminal in Frankfurt.

item.title: Powell Silence on His Future Complicates Trump Fed Chair Search
item.description: As President Donald Trump and his advisers begin weighing replacements for Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell, they’re running into one significant complication: It’s not clear that Powell will leave the US central bank next year.
item.dc:creator: Saleha Mohsin, Joshua Green, Amara Omeokwe

media:content.media:description: Jerome Powell Photographer: Al Drago/Bloomberg

item.title: US Jobs Report Slams the Door on a Fed July Rate Cut

media:content.media:description: A worker assembles a bridge ventilator in New York. Photographer: Mark Kauzlarich/Bloomberg

item.title: Bessent’s Stablecoin Hopes for Dollar Dominance Face Pushback
item.description: I’m Chris Anstey, an economics editor in Boston. Today we’re looking at potential pushback against dollar stablecoins. Send us feedback and tips to ecodaily@bloomberg.net. And if you aren’t yet signed up to receive this newsletter, you can do so here.
item.dc:creator: Chris Anstey

media:content.media:description: Scott Bessent Photographer: Annabelle Gordon/Bloomberg

item.title: For Brazil’s Criminals, Coffee Beans Are the Target
item.description: Farmers and industry groups are warning that the harvest season now underway could go down as the worst heist year in recent memory.
item.dc:creator: Sam Cowie

item.title: Trump’s US-Vietnam Trade Deal Draws China’s Stern Glare
item.description: President Donald Trump’s administration is looking to bookend the 90-day reprieve from his “Liberation Day” tariffs with at least some limited agreements announced around the US Independence Day holiday weekend.
item.dc:creator: Brendan Murray

item.title: Indonesia Says $34 Billion in Trade, Investment MOU With US in Pipeline
item.description: The US and Indonesia will sign trade and investment pacts worth $34 billion as part of Jakarta’s efforts to secure a tariff deal ahead of a July 9 deadline.
item.dc:creator: Grace Sihombing

media:content.media:description: Workers produce sports apparel at a factory in Central Java, Indonesia.

item.title: Bond Traders Eye High-Stakes US Jobs Report for Fed Rate Clues
item.description: Investors in the US Treasury market are zeroing in on a pivotal jobs report Thursday as they weigh the chances of the Federal Reserve cutting interest rates as soon as this month.
item.dc:creator: Ye Xie, Michael Mackenzie

media:content.media:description: Commuters board a train at the 14th Street-Union Square subway station in New York. Photographer: Adam Gray/Bloomberg

item.title: Savannah Bet Its Economy on a Big Hyundai Plant. Now It Has to Find the Workers
item.description: The historic city, known for gardens and gothic mystery, is leaving no stone unturned as it helps the South Korean auto giant staff up a futuristic new factory
item.dc:creator: Michael Sasso

media:content.media:description: A Boston Dynamics robot named Spot uses a camera to scan for deformities in the body of a car at the Hyundai Metaplant in Ellabell, Georgia, U.S., on Wednesday, June 11, 2025. Photographer: Elijah Nouvelage

item.title: Trump’s Vietnam Deal Shows China Tariffs Won’t Fall Much Further
item.description: President Donald Trump’s new trade deal with Vietnam sends a clear signal about where US tariffs on Chinese goods might ultimately land, as talks between Washington and Beijing continue following their recent truce.
item.dc:creator: James Mayger, Lucille Liu

item.title: Vietnam Estimates Faster GDP Growth Ahead of Tariff Deadline
item.description: Vietnam’s economy likely expanded at a faster clip of 7.67% year-on-year in the second quarter, driven by manufacturing and trade, according to Finance Minister Nguyen Van Thang.
item.dc:creator: Nguyen Dieu Tu Uyen, Nguyen Xuan Quynh

media:content.media:description: Scooter manufacturing in Hai Phong, Vietnam. Photographer: Linh Pham/Bloomberg
